Beam duct for the 1 MW neutral beam heating injector on TCV

• According to the FEA thermal transient analysis which have been performed, only the tungsten can withstands the thermal load. • The graphite is by far preferred for sputtering issues and compatibility with TCV graphite first wall, but is still problematic from a thermal viewpoint. • In terms of thermal behavior between shots, active cooling is required to lower the temperature in the extension and in the TCV VV rectangular port. • The NBH injector source is currently undergoing maintenance and improvement of the beam angular characteristics (the beam properties may change). Since the internal thermal shield seems to be challenging to set up and the temperatures for the current stainless steel beam duct or for the graphite shield insert are close to an acceptable value, the decision was taken to wait until the new source heat flux is measured at TCV. • Depending on measurements of the new injector beam a decision to either keep the current stainless steel beam duct or install a thermal shield (preferably made of graphite or possibly of tungsten) will be made on a more quantitative basis. • An apparatus to measure the heat flux at the beam duct position and options for cooling of the rectangular port are therefore the next steps to be investigated, designed, manufactured and installed for resolving the problem of the beam duct overheating.
